title: Sam Kestin describes 50 years in the Yiddish Theater
text:
Preface
This website is an active work in progress. Please follow along!
Like many other well-known names in the American Yiddish theater, Sam Kasten (written in Yiddish as “Kestin”), my great-great grandfather, published his memoirs as serialized articles in Forverts (The Forward, aka The Jewish Daily Forward). He (generally) wrote two articles per week, from September 1946 - February 1947, for a total of 45 articles (note that I added the “section dividers”.)
I obtained all memoirs articles from The National Library of Israel, and, for those newspaper editions that were not available online, from the New York Public Library’s microfiche archives.
This e-book contains my translation of these memoirs, with some important caveats:
This is an “alpha” version of the translation.
I do not (yet!) really know Yiddish (although I’ve picked up a lot along the way!), so I performed all translating by typing into Google Translate, with lots of assistance from an English-Yiddish dictionary (which, happily, includes idioms and phrases!).
I’ve completed cursory translations all of the articles, and I am now in the process of cleaning them up, posting on this website as I go. Throughout, I indicate spots where I’m very unsure of my translation, but on the whole, I think this is pretty close to what he wrote!
Where possible, I have cross-referenced items Sam discusses, as detailed in footnotes and inserted images. Unless otherwise stated, all newspaper clippings are from archives in The National Library of Israel.
As I formally begin my journey to learn Yiddish, I will likely update this translation over time as part of a long-term, living project dedicated to Sam’s life and legacy.
Many thanks to librarians at NYPL’s Dorot Division for support finding the “missing” articles! Thanks also to Steve Lasky and other volunteers who have contributed to the Museum of the Yiddish Theatre for making many translations from Zalmen Zylbercweig’s “Leksikon fun Yidishn Teater” available! They have been invaluable for cross-referencing.
In memory of Sol Glassman ז׳׳ל, whose untimely death sent me down an ancestry rabbit hole wherein I accidentally ended up at Sam (who is wholly unrelated to Sol), and discovered a treasure trove of Yiddish writings. Uniting the two sides of my family through Yiddish Theater is, simply put, beshert..

title: Sam Kestin describes 50 years in the Yiddish Theater
text: this schedule turns out to only mostly be true!↩︎

title: 1  September 7th, 1946
text:
Yiddish idiom meaning “dressed to kill”; “all dolled up”↩︎
fate/destiny↩︎
as it is known in Yiddish. In Ukrainian, “Bila Tserkva”↩︎
Ukrainian, Vasilkov↩︎
Russia abolished serfdom in 1861↩︎
 “tateh” - father↩︎
“Lion-protector of mankind”↩︎
the farmer, I believe in Ukrainian?↩︎
“mameh” - mother↩︎
“-ka” suffix is female in Ukrainian↩︎
 Graf is count/earl in Russian↩︎
 Not a good translation here.↩︎
 They lived close to many Ukrainians↩︎
 Torah teacher↩︎
Shabbat↩︎
Yom Tov; holiday↩︎

title: 2  September 19th, 1946
text:
Rebbe ↩︎
halakhic innovation; new way of doing something in orthodox Judaism↩︎
songs, tunes, “lai-dai-dai” etc.↩︎
healing↩︎
joyous occasion with religious connotation↩︎
referring to three meals of Shabbat↩︎
sermon↩︎
Torah portion↩︎
righteous man↩︎
holy power↩︎
Unclear where this is. I found something in the JewishGen database referring to “Wasilewszczyna” as a region around Vilna, which is quite far away, but perhaps?↩︎
now known as “Hrebinka”↩︎
Rybinka is indeed east of Kyiv, but not more north towards Lithuania, so again unclear where this is↩︎
formal Jewish agreement↩︎
from heaven (hebrew/religious term)↩︎
Shabbat↩︎
Shavuot↩︎
Passover↩︎

title: 3  September 21st, 1946
text:
as in, no other kinds of chasids - only Makarover↩︎
idiom: “a ruble is a trifle”; as in, money is no object↩︎
Jewish Ukrainian music? composers?↩︎
At this time in Pale of Settlement history, things were overall good for the Jews↩︎
farmer’s↩︎
joy/pride↩︎
later, he became Isaac Casten in America↩︎
kitten in the dialect↩︎
her name was Chuna -> Anna↩︎
In chasidic culture, the badchen is like a wedding singer; performs skits and sings at weddings to bring joy to the mitzvah of marriage↩︎
a popular Jewish wedding song↩︎

title: 4  September 25th, 1946
text:
farmer↩︎
just think of this as a general store - I will use that term moving forward.↩︎
term referring to an “industrious and capable wife”↩︎
“A farmer without a farm.”↩︎
literally means “room” in Hebrew, a religion-oriented school for kids (boys). Essentially, pre-yeshiva.↩︎
his mother is alive, but he still uses this term.↩︎
maybe this means ”middle of the street” in Ukrainian↩︎
literally “a good” - means favor. I’m pretty sure it’s pronounced toiva in Sam’s yiddish dialect, but it’s spelled tova (hebrew).↩︎
well this is quite the idiom..! It’s clearly not a good thing.↩︎
Literally this is some kind of little pastry or meatball, so it is probably an idiom referring to the children↩︎
synagogue↩︎
adjective, of Rybinka↩︎
derogatory term for someone who has greatly sinned↩︎
as in whipped↩︎
specifically implies he has heavily assimilated, left the orthodoxy↩︎
“topsy-turvy”↩︎
This is in fact a Jewish phrase/concept - there are seven levels of heaven.↩︎
Mikhail Efimovich Medvedev, né Meir Haimovich/Yefimiovich(?) Bernshtein. Here is another source.↩︎

title: 5  September 28th, 1946
text:
specifically the goyishe farmers↩︎
righteous, holy man; often used to describe chasidic rebbes↩︎
this is either an idiom, or perhaps it refers to farming?↩︎
refers to the tsarist Russia governance police superintendent↩︎
refers to the tsarist Russia local police↩︎
remember, there are six children: two boys and four girls. So far, one boy and one girl have married↩︎
This is definitely Ukrainian, no idea what it means - but probably something good?↩︎
specifically means they illegally crossed the border↩︎
Yiddish name for Brody, Ukraine. At the time, Brody was part of Poland; it went back and forth as it is right around the border of Poland/Ukraine↩︎
a bribe↩︎
Recall this is being written in 1946 when there are many Jewish refugees with nowhere to go after the Holocaust↩︎
here, implies crazy thoughts↩︎
in other words, America is not just for play↩︎
At this time, the Jewish district in Philadelphia was roughly Locust - Christian, 8th - Front. The stretch of Bainbridge between 4th-5th was a market, so I imagine Sam was around that area.↩︎

title: 6  October 3rd, 1946
text:
nigun is song, “dl” suffix is a little endearment↩︎
written “Americaner boi”: אמעריקאנער באי↩︎
“homey”, implying a comfort/ease↩︎
he keeps a sense of humor about everything↩︎
songs: lidel is a song, so lidlach is a little song, like a little ditty↩︎
his Lekskion (encyclopedia) entry suggests he sold matches for about a year↩︎
implies someone from the same region in the old country as him↩︎
שירט–מעיקער↩︎
“bracha” - blessing↩︎
An operetta by Abraham Goldfaden, the father of Yiddish theater. - Play synopsis.↩︎
Another Abraham Goldfaden operetta - Play synopsis.↩︎
A literal verb “chazan” here, meaning they chanted/sang religiously inspired tunes you might expect in a cantorial setting↩︎
little bits of chazan music↩︎
unclear idiom here, but presumably a good thing - filling the air maybe?↩︎
Below I’ve directly written the Hebrew (not Yiddish) as Sam wrote it out. This is a liturgical tune?↩︎
has a positive connotation here↩︎
Jews attended a shul that founded by their landsmen. The “Russian Shul” is B’nei Abraham, which today is a chabad shul on Lombard between 5th-6th.↩︎
This is the city’s Hebrew; it means “white fields”↩︎
This is the city’s Yiddish name: “black sin/uncleanliness/derogatory term for church”, which is a play on words since the Ukrainian name, “Bila Tserkva,” means “white church”↩︎
ruckus; again, here it is a positive connotation↩︎
specific prayers, but can also refer to full services. So, Sam may have acted as chazan.↩︎
Or, Yiddish; Yiddish means Jewish, so it’s the same word.↩︎
This would have taken place no later than 1887↩︎
a manager, other staff - not one of the actors↩︎
has a specific connotation of people who would be excited/eager to be extras↩︎
This is Sam’s first performance - as an extra in “Shulamith”↩︎
commoner or lowly person; these are roles in the show↩︎
Avisholem’s servant and an African. This role almost certainly would have been played in black face.↩︎
See her Leksikon entry here↩︎
See his Leksikon entry here↩︎
This is a play on words: In German, “adler” means eagle. Therefore, he was generally referred to as “nesher hagadol” (נשר הגדול), which means “great eagle” in Hebrew.↩︎

title: 7  October 10th, 1946
text:
If you need a hoard of commoners, get some locals to be extras!↩︎
“Raisins and Almonds”, a well known Yiddish lullaby originally from Shulamis.↩︎
You can find the full lyrics in English and transliterated Yiddish here.↩︎
idiom - they really enjoyed it, as in “finger-licking good”↩︎
This, and other bolded words, were bolded in the original article. Fun fact: In Yiddish, they emphasize words spacing them out, so for example this was actually written: “M o g u l e s k o.”↩︎
Nickname “Zelig;” he was the most beloved comedian of the early Yiddish theater, bar none. Read his Leksikon entry here. He and Sam would later become close friends, and Sam loved and admired him dearly.↩︎
it was the early days of Yiddish theater - it was catching on and becoming popular, bigger, etc.↩︎
Literally translated as “The Coquettish Ladies,” this comedy was written by the famous author/playwright Shomer. ↩︎
From cross-referencing in his Leksikon entry, we know this took place in 1887.↩︎
He made a serious impact playing this role. Incidentally,Bessie Thomashefsky (who we will meet later) also attended this show in Philadelphia. In her memoirs, she dedicates a whole chapter to how much she loved seeing Mogulesko in this role.↩︎
You can find the full lyrics in Yiddish here, starting at the number 1. halfway down the page.↩︎
idiom; “really enjoyed”↩︎
or, “how inspired I was”↩︎
It it worth noting that they generally referred to fellows Jews as “Jew” rather than, here for example, “man”↩︎
Yiddish endearment nickname for “Zelig”↩︎
Sam literally wrote: “suddenly everything I was going to say before went out of my head”↩︎
audacity, insolence↩︎
In Yiddish theater, roles were often quite tied to the actor who originated them (not unlike today!). For example, when you played one of Mogulesko’s roles, your performance might reflect poorly on him as much as on you.↩︎
This is Hebrew; means “in silence”. You can find the full lyrics in Yiddish here.↩︎
common sense↩︎
As in, the song sings about several different people (in the subsequent verses)↩︎
pious↩︎
as in, at work↩︎

title: 8  October 12th, 1946
text:
In this memoir article, the newspaper began including little introductions of what the article contains.↩︎
Known in Yiddish as “Di kishefmakherin” (the “spell-maker”) or “Bobe Yachne” (this is the witch’s name). You can read a synopsis here. This play was recently revived by the Folksbiene (NYT review).↩︎
I am not entirely confident in this translation, but I think it is roughly correct at least in terms of the sentiment. She may be referring to Bessie Thomashefshky, who has already run away with Boris - and is her niece.↩︎
Word does not translate: אויפטוער↩︎
Indeed, Gartenstein was arrested in Philadelphia in 1888 for cheating people out of money and not paying debts.↩︎
See Illinois 5 in this wikipedia article. Also, it was a contested election!.↩︎
קאַמפּעין–ספּיטשעס↩︎
This was written in 1946, so 56 years ago was 1890.↩︎
Recall he was in the play Shulamith where Sam was an extra in Chapter 6.↩︎
This term is used generally to refer to areas of the country that are outside the big cities.↩︎
homegrown/local talent↩︎
And likely so was Suzie, his future wife; she also played with Gartenstein in Philadelphia although we do not have as many details on her life.↩︎
the witch’s servant↩︎
refers to a theater “cue”, as in you say your line on your cue.↩︎
means authentic, genuine↩︎
songs↩︎
as in bupkis!↩︎
he’s acting crazy↩︎

title: 9  October 17th, 1946
text:
These are two separate taglines. These were not her last words to him.↩︎
System of payment in which each actor in the company received an agreed percentage of any profits according to their “stamp.”↩︎
my translation; Sam uses “poor, miserable”↩︎
Phrase in Yiddish meaning to be dirt poor. So, he was not making a living with this.↩︎
Read his Lekiskon entry here.↩︎
the “holy tongue”; refers to Hebrew↩︎
Based on Bessie Thomashefsky’s memoirs (Read her Lekiskon entry), this would have been during the first few days of Pesach; So, likely either late March 1888, or late April 1889.↩︎
someone from same region in the old country↩︎
Located at the northeast corner of 5th and Gaskill, right above South Street.↩︎
He would soon become a major figure in Yiddish theater in America; at this time, he was young and recently married to Bessie. Read Boris’ Leksikon entry here. It’s also worth noting that Boris & his troupe were already in Philadelphia in competition with Gartenstein, and moreover we know from Bessie’s memoir that in fact they approached Sam, and not vice versa, to invite him into their troupe. It was not too difficult to convince him, in part, because Sam and Bessie are cousins.↩︎
This is an old Goldfaden play, but there is little information on it.↩︎
Rabbi’s assistant, essentially; this would be an extremely religious character.↩︎
According to Bessie’s memoirs, Sam played in their troupe during the summer of 1889.↩︎
songs↩︎
“home”↩︎
This is right by Rosenhayn, a Jewish agricultural colony in Cumberland County↩︎
She uses an idiom here that I can’t find the right words for; she says “What can you to do help yourself…”↩︎

title: 10  October 19th, 1946
text:
The play “The Two Kuni Lemels” is one of Goldfaden’s most famous plays. In the 1960s, it was made into an Israeli film.↩︎
Neighborhood in Brooklyn that was extremely Jewish through the 1950s.↩︎
$10 in the 1890s equates to roughly $340 today (2023)↩︎
Unclear if this is a correct translation - that he wasn’t scared of NYC.↩︎
implies they would do anything for them; “come hell or high water” these fans are ready to defend their actors.↩︎
Hebrew translated from his name: schoen <-> yaffa and gold <-> zahav↩︎
He was introduced in Chapter 6.↩︎
Again, another Hebrew play on words, described in Chapter 6 footnotes.↩︎
A town outside of the major cities↩︎
As in, he’ll just figure it out when he gets on the stage!↩︎
This may not be a correct translation, but it’s the right vibe.↩︎
He passed away in 1942, according to his Leksikon entry, in Los Angeles where he settled when he became older and ill.↩︎
סטאַר ספּעשעלטי קלאָב↩︎
This was Max Staller, a prominent anarchist, who was also the first president of the Mount Sinai hospital in Philadelphia. There is a bit more information about him on Find a Grave.↩︎
It’s worth noting that, according to the book Jewish Quarter of Philadelphia: A History & Guide 1881-1930, the “Star Specialty Club” troupe would sometimes play at the old fire station at 512 S 3rd St, right above South St.↩︎
“The Free Voice of Labor”; Anarchist Yiddish newspaper↩︎
God forbid↩︎
a very common profession in the new world!↩︎
big fan↩︎
Literally “spinning head,” an idiom that refers to a schemer/swindler. They talk so much they spin your head around.↩︎
aka, landsmen - people from the same region in the old country↩︎
An aside: In the musical Man of La Mancha, “The Barber’s Song” includes the line, “Thou and I now, ere I die now, will make golden history!” Irving Jacobson, a famous Yiddish theater actor/director, originated in the role of Sancho. The lyricist was Joe Darion, who at least at some point worked in the Yiddish arts. In conclusion, Man of La Mancha is, indeed, the Yiddish theater.↩︎
not New York↩︎
means, “came back empty-handed”↩︎
I’ve rephrased from an idiom that doesn’t translate well↩︎
I changed this from “tumult in the world for you”. It’s a conversational idiom - implies, you want to be famous in NYC?!↩︎
Almost certainly idiom for “they will love you”↩︎
implying, you don’t have to go crazy looking for somewhere↩︎
סוזי שעיפער↩︎
the word Sam uses translates to “withdrawal”; I think he is referring to her introversion↩︎

title: 11  October 24th, 1946
text:
Yiddish culture; it’s likely he is referring to Jewish culture here↩︎
Shabbat↩︎
heretic↩︎
Recall, in 1946 when Sam was writing this, Brownsville was still 100% Jewish↩︎
This is not likely a correct translation, at all. Yiddish: די ציגען און די בלאָטעם↩︎
These regions all have different Yiddish dialects. Litvaks are Lithuanian/northeastern, and Galicianers are from the Galicia region, which is now part of Poland and western Ukraine↩︎
I can’t find what song he is referring to: קעהלע↩︎
Blood libel↩︎
Most Yiddish plays at this time had two names, and Sam is being funny about it↩︎
Boris wrote this based on a play written previously by Shimon Beckerman.↩︎
Almost certainly they are first cousins - their mothers are probably sisters↩︎
Recall, they had also acted together in Philadelphia for the summer of probably 1888 or 1889↩︎
Sam and Charlie later became very close friends. Along with Sam’s son Louis, Charlie was with Sam when he passed away. However, Sam is almost certainly mis-remembering meeting Charlie in Brownsville. Charlie was born in 1886, and these events are taking place in 1892-93 when Charlie would still have been a child living in the Lower East Side (details confirmed by Charlie’s obituary in the Forverts). ↩︎
In fact, as we know from an article Sam wrote in 1913, his friend Jacob Frank suggested to him that if you’re going to starve to death (Sam was eating maybe 1 piece of bread a day), you might as well get married first.↩︎
implying all proceeds go to support them↩︎
Not a leading man anymore↩︎
presumably meaning “poorer”↩︎
In other words, there are no rules↩︎
What else would they do?↩︎
Again, Charlie Cohan was not playing there - Sam is mis-remembering↩︎
This sentence may be a fundamentally wrong translation, but I think it could be ok too! Either way, it makes sense for the context.↩︎

title: 12  October 26th, 1946
text:
Max Karp, introduced in chapter 6↩︎
מן המצר; This song title is derived from Pslam 118.↩︎
Lower East Side↩︎
Their first son Freddie was born in 1894. He would later go on to fight in WWI, during which he was exposed to mustard gas and was chronically ill with severe lung problems for the rest of his life, until he passed away in 1935 from associated complications. He worked in the theater box offices and similar before he passed.↩︎
Recall, Sam is Boris’ wife Bessie’s cousin↩︎
an idiom meaning crowded↩︎
Sam writes, “as was always his manner”↩︎
diaspora/exile; this is a hebrew word: גלות↩︎
Sing along at the link!↩︎
my translation; Sam wrote Mogulesko created for the stage↩︎

title: 13  October 31st, 1946
text:
Something is missing in translation here. Perhaps the previous sentence has a different connotation.↩︎
mercy, grace, benevolence↩︎
perhaps this implies assimilated: אלט–געזעסענע↩︎
Not sure this is exactly correct, could be “Jewish community/collective”?; he writes: אידישען כלל↩︎
According to Joseph Rumshinsky’s account of Yiddish theater history, this play was based on the German play “The Night Wanderer.”↩︎
Must be a character in the show, unrelated to the fact that this is Sam’s name!↩︎
Recall, a system where each actor gets a pre-specified percentage of profits↩︎
He says, like Purim!, נאריש↩︎
שלח–מנות; Basket of gifts/sweets you give to family and friends at Purim. I am assuming there is a Yiddish parable/short story about a poor boy who brings them around and the following happens..↩︎
joy, happiness↩︎
as in, he did all the little things↩︎

title: 14  November 2nd, 1946
text:
This is an idiom, meaning to be starving - after all, if you aren’t eating, you don’t need your teeth anymore so you can put them on the shelf. In Yiddish: פאַרוואַרפען די ציין אויף די בענטאַנעס ↩︎
in his Ukrainian Yiddish dialect↩︎
Recall, Israel bought Sam’s farm in Bridgeton, Cumberland County, NJ↩︎
His old friend Jacob Frank from Philadelphia (recall, Star Specialty Club), and they had gone to Brownsville together. Jacob either stayed in Brownsville while Sam was in Boston or toured elsewhere in the country.↩︎
Read the whole play, in Yiddish, in Google Books.↩︎
The Jews loved their show tunes!↩︎
עכט–יידיש↩︎
You can sing along too with the first two verses, with lyrics in Yiddish and English!↩︎
This translation is from Yiddish Penny Songs, but rearranged to better match the order of words in Yiddish. The lyrics at the link are somewhat rearranged for English speakers.↩︎
Abraham↩︎
Torah, in book (not scroll) form↩︎
Moses↩︎
Indeed, his full set of lyrics may be among the last remaining transcriptions.↩︎

Article in The Jewish Exponent: “History’s Lessons: Jewish Anarchist Doctors Cared for Philadelphia’s Immigrants”

title: Appendix A: Glossary of people
text:
Though his career was predominantly in the American theater, in his teens he was an “errand-boy” for Yiddish actors in Boston.↩︎
He was the manager of Sam’s acting troupe in Philadelphia, the “Star Specialty Club,” in the late 1880s-early 1890s.↩︎
